segment.source: In OpenGL ES 2.0, shaders return data after execution using intrinsics such as glPosition, glFragColor, or glFragDatan (where n is the index for a specific render target).

segment.source: In Direct3D, there are no specific intrinsics, and the shaders return data as the return type of their respective main() functions.
segment.target: In Direct3D, there are no specific intrinsics, and the shaders return data as the return type of their respective main() functions.

segment.source: For pixel shaders, SVTARGETn, which indicates a render target, is required on the body method.

segment.source: Also note that vertex shaders are required to output the SVPOSITION system value semantic.
segment.target: Also note that vertex shaders are required to output the SVPOSITION system value semantic.

segment.source: This semantic resolves the vertex position data to coordinate values where x is between -1 and 1, y is between -1 and 1, z is divided by the original homogeneous coordinate w value (z/w), and w is 1 divided by the original w value (1/w).
segment.target: This semantic resolves the vertex position data to coordinate values where x is between -1 and 1, y is between -1 and 1, z is divided by the original homogeneous coordinate w value (z/w), and w is 1 divided by the original w value (1/w).

segment.source: Pixel shaders use the SVPOSITION system value semantic to retrieve the pixel location on the screen, where x is between 0 and the render target width and y is between 0 and the render target height (each offset by 0.5).
segment.target: Pixel shaders use the SVPOSITION system value semantic to retrieve the pixel location on the screen, where x is between 0 and the render target width and y is between 0 and the render target height (each offset by 0.5).

segment.source: Understanding HLSL semantics and the packing of constant buffers can save you a bit of a debugging headache, as well as provide optimization opportunities.
segment.target: Understanding HLSL semantics and the packing of constant buffers can save you a bit of a debugging headache, as well as provide optimization opportunities.

segment.source: If you get a chance, read through Variable Syntax (HLSL), Introduction to Buffers in Direct3D 11, and How to: Create a Constant Buffer.
segment.target: If you get a chance, read through Variable Syntax (HLSL), Introduction to Buffers in Direct3D 11, and How to: Create a Constant Buffer.

segment.source: If not, though, here's a few starting tips to keep in mind about semantics and constant buffers:
segment.target: If not, though, here's a few starting tips to keep in mind about semantics and constant buffers:

segment.source: Always double check your renderer's Direct3D configuration code to make sure that the structures for your constant buffers match the cbuffer struct declarations in your HLSL, and that the component scalar types match across both declarations.
segment.target: Always double check your renderer's Direct3D configuration code to make sure that the structures for your constant buffers match the cbuffer struct declarations in your HLSL, and that the component scalar types match across both declarations.

segment.source: In your renderer's C++ code, use DirectXMath types in your constant buffer declarations to ensure proper data packing.
segment.target: In your renderer's C++ code, use DirectXMath types in your constant buffer declarations to ensure proper data packing.

segment.source: The best way to efficiently use constant buffers is to organize shader variables into constant buffers based on their frequency of update.
segment.target: The best way to efficiently use constant buffers is to organize shader variables into constant buffers based on their frequency of update.

segment.source: For example, if you have some uniform data that is updated once per frame, and other uniform data that is updated only when the camera moves, consider separating that data into two separate constant buffers.
segment.target: For example, if you have some uniform data that is updated once per frame, and other uniform data that is updated only when the camera moves, consider separating that data into two separate constant buffers.

segment.target: Semantics that you have forgotten to apply or which you have applied incorrectly will be your earliest source of shader compilation (FXC) errors.
